title: Do people who write bad novels know they are writing bad novels? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think it depends on the author. Some surely know it and don’t care, so long as they receive a royalty check. Others probably aren’t aware they’re bad writers and simply love what they’re doing. As an editor, I’ve received some truly trash books and there’s only so much I can do to pull them up out of the mire. Some authors don’t really care if what they’re writing is crap, they know they can still publish it through Smashwords or Kindle. Price it at .99 cents and someone will buy it. Even if they don’t finish it, it’s only .99 cents so who’s going to complain? This works, because tons and tons of people have that mindset, so the author is making a decent amount for crummy work, and that’s fine with them. I have actually had a client tell me, when I informed her that there’s a line between writing erotica and just describing explicit sexual acts, that her readers don’t care about the content, they just want to read something that gets them going. As an author it can be frustrating to see the plethora of muck that comes out on a daily basis. On the other hand though, I’ll be the first to admit that my first published book wasn’t ready to be published, and nor was I at the tender age of 20. I didn’t know what I was doing, my writing was still a bit childish, and I didn’t understand the requirements of the publishing world. I know that book is not the best, though I stand by the story and will until I die. The story itself is golden. The mistakes I made were hard lessons learned and my subsequent books are much much better. It boils down to listening to editors, agents, publishers, and reviewers. As much as we hate to admit it, they do actually know what they’re on about, and will only make you better as a writer. The people who don’t listen are the people who don’t care, and will continue to inundate the market with drivel.

I think that everyone who is writing their first novel that it is going to be bad since you don’t have the same amount of experience as professional authors. Getting your first novel to make it to print through a traditional publish is going to be really hard, and there will be a lot of rejection, but with more practice you should get better the more you write. Although there are some people who believe they are amazing writers, but are actually writing bad novels. My sister has a teacher (she's in middle school) that published his book through amazon and tells all his students about them since they aren't very successful. If a traditional publisher or agent tells you they don’t think it’s good enough, ask them for suggestions on how to improve, and please, please, please take their advice. Don't assume your first novel is the masterpiece this world has been waiting for, because it most likely isn't and you don’t want to ruin your chances in the field by publishing something you’ll regret later on.

Not a bad question. I can only speak for myself, but when I’m writing poorly, I know it. And I fix it. Before I started my first work of fiction I read lots of the best in my genre. When I finally got to the point where I could honestly say to myself, “I can do that. I can write that well,” I started writing and kept at it, reading writing craft books and, well, just plain reading. And continuing to write. Another part of the process is getting solid outside feedback along the way. When my editors and beta readers said “Wow, this is good stuff,” I knew I was on the right track.

There have been some great answers here, so I just want to add in my optimistic nickel: almost every first draft of a novel is bad, regardless of writing style or talent. (Unless if you’re Robert Louis Stevenson. We don’t talk about him.) We need refinement, our skills need to mature, and we figure that stuff out by working on our first project. It isn’t for everyone. It’s hard work. I can only imagine that putting in that hard work helps people to assume that, because they’re getting better, they’re good. If you’re writing a novel, keep writing it. Don’t think about if you’re good, don’t think about your style - write, keep writing. Let it build, let it flow, let your confidence and research shape your story into a quality narrative.

I believe that if a writer doesn’t know he wrote a bad novel, he would soon find out when the publisher refuses to publish it, or if the critics overlook it altogether, or if it doesn’t sell well once it is in the shop. But you don’t specify what you mean by ‘bad novel’; badly written, superficial content? It has happened that some famous writer heavily criticised the newly published novel of another famous writer, as was the case for James Joyce‘s (famous) Ulysses when it came out. One such critic, which I shall not name, had said “It’s rubbish’, though s/he changed her/his opinion later. But, this has nothing to do with what you meant by ‘bad novels’, does it?

I suppose you could say that since writing is “subjective” then they aren’t bad novels or writers. But I can tell you that I have read/listened to some novels and wondered “how did anyone publish this?” I’ve read novels that were so “acclaimed” (for their time I guess) and still heralded as remarkable and renowned literature. I found this to be true with a lot of novels, but then there are some that I just do not get. When I read/listen to novels I list them on a spreadsheet, rate them 1 through 10 by narrator and story and then I rate them for myself as well on Amazon. I just finished listening to my seven hundred and third auto novel. There are some I wish I never wasted my time and others I wonder “How come no one made a movie about this yet?” So I guess the answer is, It’s all subjective.

Absolutely not. If you think about it, the worse the writer the less his self-criticism skills. Meaning the following: A good writer wil consider himself an average one at best (or worse). A very bad writer will consider himself a very good writer. And an extremely bad writer will consider himself a genious. And trust me on this one for I am talking about first hand experience.

Someone on FB made comments about how a person needed connections to get anyone to read their book or published. I offered to read his book. It was really bad from a reader’s perspective. I didn’t think it was a complete loss, though and provided a few recommendations. I was told that I didn't understand. He was writing a serous SF about a conflict on a planet and relationships didn’t matter. His grammar was perfect and didn’t need to be corrected…etc (BTW he was starting paragraphs out with the word And). I learned my lesson - I’m not going to try and help anyone again unless they specifically asked. In his case he didn’t recognize his story had issues. I do recognize my own book has editing issues, but that’s another story, I just hope people don’t let editing get in the way of the story.

Not usually. It is very difficult to assess the merits of your own work. What you think is great one day may seem terrible another. I reevaluate my own work all the time. All that being said, if a book is really not working, you may instinctively know it. It will lose dramatic impact at a certain point. It will just not have the right feel.
